column1: \ Welcome! This is a template for your own plain-text reading list.
\ This file can be turned into a pretty webpage at Plain Reading (https://plainreading.com): just register for an account
column2: then upload your reading.csv file
column3: or connect to your Dropbox where you have it saved.

column1: \ Any line in this file starting with a backslash (\) is a comment and will be ignored by Plain Reading.
\ Feel free to delete these explanatory comments once you don't need to refer back to them anymore.
\ You can edit this file in any spreadsheet app or text editor. When you open the file
column2: be sure to select the pipe character (|) as the column separator.

column1: \ If you use VS Code
column2: try the Rainbow CSV extension: https://marketplace.visualstudio.com/items?itemName=mechatroner.rainbow-csv. Be sure to set VS Code's Language Mode to "CSV (pipe)".

column1: \ For editing in VS Code or other text editors
column2: you might want to make a hotkey to set up a new column instantly. This way you won't have to type out all the column dividers and today's date. For more on that
column3: see https://github.com/fpsvogel/plain-reading/doc/autohotkey-reading-csv.ahk

column1: \ â•’â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â••
\   ğŸ™¥ THE BASICS ğŸ™¦
\ â•˜â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•›
\ Now let's take a look at how your reading.csv should be formatted. Here is the beginning of a minimal reading list:
\Author - Title|Dates finished
\------ IN PROGRESS
Sapiens: A Brief History of Humankind
Tom Holt - Goatsong: A Novel of Ancient Athens -- The Walled Orchard
\ Columns are divided by a pipe character (|).
\ This means you *must not* use the pipe character anywhere except to divide columns.
\ At the top we have the column headers.
\ Next is a section header. "In progress" means items that you're currently reading
column2: watching
column3: etc.

column1: \ Notice that these headers (the first two lines) are comments. They are for your convenience and don't need to be formatted in any particular way.
\ Then we have two items
column2: books in this case.

column1: \ As you can see
column2: the author is optional. The first item omits it.

column1: \ You're currently re-reading the second item: it has two "Dates finished"
column2: making this your third time reading it. Nice!

column1: \ Dates can have leading zeroes ("06" in "2019/06/18") or omit them ("2020/5/8")
column2: whichever you prefer.

column1: \ Dates must be in order. By default the direction is left-to-right (earlier dates on the left)
column2: but you can switch the direction in Plain Reading's Settings.

column1: \ If this minimal kind of reading list is what you want
column2: just be sure to go to the Settings page in Plain Reading and disable the columns that you don't want to use
column3: so that your reading.csv can be properly parsed and turned into a pretty webpage.

column1: \ You could go even more minimalist and disable the Dates Finished column if you just want to keep a list of titles of books you've read.
\ But by default
column2: all columns are enabled. Here are those same two items
column3: but now with all columns:

column1: \Rating|Format
column2: Author
column3: Title|Sources
column4: ISBN/ASIN|Dates added > Started

column1: \------ IN PROGRESS
|ğŸ”ŠSapiens: A Brief History of Humankind|Vail Library B00ICN066A|2021/06/11 > 2021/09/20| |history
column2: wisdom|15:17|Ch. 5: "We did not domesticate wheat. It domesticated us." -- End of ch. 8: the ubiquity of patriarchal societies is so far unexplained. It would make more sense for women (being on average more socially adept) to have formed a matriarchal society as among the bonobos. -- Ch. 19: are we happier in modernity? It's doubtful.|History with a sociological bent
column3: with special attention paid to human happiness.

column1: 5|50% ğŸ“•Tom Holt - Goatsong: A Novel of Ancient Athens -- The Walled Orchard
\ Wow. That's a lot. But again
column2: you can go to Settings and disable the columns that you don't want.

column1: \ And even when they are all enabled
column2: you don't *have* to fill in every column every time. For example
column3: the first item above omits the first column and the last two columns. The second item also omits the last few columns
column4: except for History. (It seems you were inspired to carefully track of your re-reading of the book in 2020.) See the Appendix at the bottom for details on History.

column1: \ The title is the only piece of information that's required on every line. Everything else is optional.
\ On the Settings page in Plain Reading
column2: you can also hide individual pieces of information
column3: if you want to have them in your reading.csv but not in your pretty webpage.

column1: \ Many other things are customizable in Settings
column2: such as the rating scale (1-5
column4: etc.) and the formats and their emojis.

column1: \ â•’â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â••
\         ğŸ™¥ THE KITCHEN SINK ğŸ™¦
\  â˜™ advanced (but useful) features â§
\ â•˜â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•›
\ Here are a few more examples.
\ If at any point you wonder
column2: "Why do I have to do it exactly this way
column3: when Plain Reading doesn't even show all this information in My List?" the answer is that this information *is* being parsed and saved by Plain Reading
column4: and will play a part in upcoming features such as a Statistics page.

column1: \ This time
column2: let's list items that you've finished.

column1: \Rating|Format
column2: Author
column3: Title|Sources
column4: ISBN/ASIN|Dates added > Started

column1: 4|ğŸ“•Robert Louis Stevenson - Insula Thesauraria -- in Mount Hope Classics -- trans. Arcadius Avellanus -- unabridged|1533694567|2020/10/20 ğŸ¤ğŸ¼ weekly Latin reading with Sean and Dennis|2021/08/31|latin
column2: novel|8:18|Paper on Avellanus by Patrick Owens: https://linguae.weebly.com/arcadius-avellanus.html -- Arcadius Avellanus: Erasmus Redivivus (1947): https://ur.booksc.eu/book/18873920/05190d

column1: 2|ğŸ”ŠTotal Cat Mojo|gift from neighbor Edith B01NCYY3BV|DNF 50% 2020/03/21
column4: for friends|10:13|I would've felt bad if I hadn't tried.

column1: 1|DNF ğŸ¤FiveThirtyEight Politics ğŸ¤The NPR Politics Podcast ğŸ¤Pod Save America| |2021/08/02|2021/08/02|politics
column2: podcast
column3: for starred friends|0:30|Not very deep. Disappointing.

column1: 5|Randall Munroe - What If?: Serious Scientific Answers to Absurd Hypothetical Questions|ğŸ”ŠLexpub B00LV2F1ZA 6:36 -- unabridged -- published 2016 âš¡Amazon B00IYUYF4A 320 -- published 2014|2021/08/01
column2: 2021/08/16 v2 ğŸ¤ğŸ¼ with Sam
column10: Neutron Bullet.|It's been a long time since I gave highest marks to a "just for fun" book
column12: this was fun. So fun that after listening to the audiobook
column13: I immediately proceeded to read the book
column14: for its illustrations. If I'd read this as a kid
column15: I might have been inspired to become a scientist.

column1: \ "Robert Louisâ€¦":  The series ("Mount Hope Classics") comes after a special word: "in" (must be lowercase).
\ Extra info can also be indicated after the title: in this example
column2: the translator and the fact that this book is unabridged.

column1: \ The series and extra info can appear in any order. This could have been "â€¦ Thesauraria -- unabridged - in Mount Hope Classics - trans. Arcadius Avellanus".
\ Two hyphens surrounded by a space (" -- ") are the divider before series
column2: before extra info
column3: between notes
column4: and (as we'll see in the last example of this section) between item variants.

column1: \ Also
column2: you can include the group experience emoji (ğŸ¤ğŸ¼) after a date started. If you write a note after the emoji
column3: it will be shown in your public notes by default. In Plain Reading's Settings you can choose not to show group experiences.

column1: \ "Total Cat Mojo": DNF means "Did Not Finish". You can specify your stopping point with a percentage
column2: a length such as "55p" or "1:03". Or you can not specify it at all
column3: as in the next example. If you don't specify the stopping point or if the stopping point was the same each time you read it
column4: you can just write "DNF" once before the format and title

column1: 2|DNF 50% ğŸ”ŠTotal Cat Mojo|â€¦

\ Also in this example we have "for friends" in the Genres column. This makes the item visible only to your friends on Plain Reading. (Maybe you don't want the whole world to know that you listened to a cat audiobookâ€¦ twice.) The other visibility levels are "for starred friends" (or "for starred") and "for me" (or "private" if you prefer). Or you can use "to" instead of "for"
column2: and/or hyphens instead of spaces
column3: e.g. "to me"
column4: "to-me"
column5: or "for-me". Besides these per-item visibility markers
column6: you'll find lots of global visibility options in Settings.

column1: \ "FiveThirtyEightâ€¦": Here we see a multi-item line. This is most useful when you DNF'ed several items and equally disliked them. But a multi-item line doesn't *have* to be DNF.
\ "Randallâ€¦": This is an item that you re-read as a different *variant*: in this example
column2: the first variant is an audiobook from Lexpub
column3: and the second variant is an ebook from Amazon.

column1: \ - In the Sources column you can describe each variant with these data
column2: in this order: format
column3: source(s)
column4: ISBN/ASIN
column6: and/or extra info. These are all formatted in the same way as usual.

column1: \ - If a variant omits data that can also be in other columns (format
column2: length
column3: extra info)
column4: then this data in the variant will be defined by other columns rather than being blank. So if these data are the same across all variants
column5: you can write them down just once in the other columns.

column1: \ - The exception is progress (without "DNF") before the title
column2: which only applies to the most recent date. See the second In Progress example earlier: the "50%" before the title describes the current re-reading of the book
column3: not the previous readings.

column1: \ - Variants can be separated either by format emojis or (if you omit the emojis) by a double hyphen with a space around it (" -- "). But if you have any extra info in Sources
column2: that divider is already being used there
column3: so in that case you *must* include format emojis even if all the variants have the same format.

column1: \ - If you include any format emojis in Sources
column2: then you have to include them for every variant. But the other data can be specified in some variants and not in others.

column1: \ - Now let's look at the Date Started column. After each date started you can specify the variant to which it refers with "v" followed by a number
column2: such as "v2" for the second variant
column3: "v3" for the third
column4: and so on.

column1: \ - A date started with no variant specified refers to the first variant. In this example
column2: you listened to the audiobook in the first half of August
column3: then you read the ebook in the second half of August
column4: and then in September you listened to the audiobook again.

column1: \ Whew! That covers all the odd cases that Plain Reading handles
column2: except for the History column
column3: which I've relegated to the Appendix at the bottom since not everyone is soâ€¦ *careful* as to want to track every page of every day.

column1: \ I'm open to new ideas
column2: so if you want to add an item in your reading.csv in a different way that Plain Reading *can't* handle currently
column3: then please let me know by adding a feature request at https://github.com/fpsvogel/plain-reading/issues

column1: \ â•’â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â••
\      ğŸ™¥ BACK TO THE FUTURE ğŸ™¦
\  â˜™ jotting down planned items â§
\ â•˜â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•›
\ There's one last thing left: planned items
column2: your "to read" list. One way to track this is to have normal items
column3: but without a date started
column4: and (if you want) with a date added
column5: which is marked by a semicolon after it.

column1: \------ PLANNED
|âš¡Tom Holt - A Song for Nero|B00GW4U2TM| | |historical fiction|580
|ğŸ“•Randall Munroe - How To: Absurd Scientific Advice for Common Real-World Problems|Lexpub B07NCQTJV3|2021/06/27 >| |science|320
\ But this method has two disadvantages for listing books that you just *might* read: (a) it takes more time than just jotting down the title
column2: and (b) it takes up a lot of space if you have a long "to read" list.

column1: \ Here is a quicker and more compact way to jot down planned items:
\------ PLANNED
\HISTORICAL FICTION: âš¡Tom Holt - A Song for Nero
column2: ğŸ”ŠTrue Grit @Little Library
column3: @Hoopla
column4: ğŸ”ŠTwo Gentlemen of Lebowski @Lexpub

column1: \SCIENCE: ğŸ“•Randall Munroe - How To: Absurd Scientific Advice for Common Real-World Problems @Lexpub
column2: ğŸ”ŠOn the Origin of Species
column3: ğŸ”ŠWeird Earth @Hoopla

column1: \ For Plain Reading to parse planned these compact planned items
column2: you must:

column1: \ - Include the format emoji before each title.
\ - Start the line with a comment character
column2: then a single genre in all caps
column3: then a colon (:).

column1: \ The all-caps genre is changed to lowercase in Plain Reading. So if you have a "science" genre
column2: the items after "SCIENCE" here will be in that same "science" genre.

column1: \ At the end of an item you can list sources
column2: each immediately preceded by "@".

column1: \ By default
column2: planned items are visible only to friends.

column1: \ To change this and other settings
column2: and to discover even more features not covered here
column3: see the Settings page: https://plainreading.com/settings

column1: \ â•’â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â••
\       ğŸ™¥ APPENDIX ğŸ™¦
\  â˜™ the History column â§
\ â•˜â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•›
\ The History column is handy if you want to track your reading/watching/listening in detail.
\ In the future
column2: Plain Reading will have a Statistics page where you can see charts about your reading habits. For Plain Reading to understand your reading histories
column3: they must be written in a particular way. Here are some examples:

column1: 4|ğŸï¸Eyes on the Prize: America's Civil Rights Movement|https://worldchannel.org/show/eyes-on-the-prize/ https://jeffco.kanopy.com/video/eyes-prize|2021/07/28
4|ğŸ¤Escriba CafÃ©|https://www.escribacafe.com/| | |portuguese
column2: history
column3: podcast| | |Most Portuguese podcasts are annoyingly chatty
column4: but this one is the opposite: historical yarns intended to transport you into another time and place.||2021/7/12 0:20 Bella Luna

column1: \ "Eyes on the Prize": You can use a URL as a source
column2: and you can list multiple sources.

column1: \ This is is also an example of more detailed tracking with the History column
column2: a comma-separated list of dates when you made progress on an item.

column1: \ - Only the first date needs to be written out in full.
\ - The length of your progress should appear after the date: in this case
column2: one hour on the 28th of July.

column1: \ - Length can be omitted wherever it is the same as the one last indicated. All of the episodes in this series are one hour long
column2: so in this case the "1:00" after the other dates would be unnecessary
column3: and so it's omitted.

column1: \ - "x5" and "x4" mean "five times" and "four times": on the 31st you watched five episodes
column2: and on the 1st you watched four episodes. Then on the 2nd and 3rd you went back to watching just one episode per day as before. (You could also do "7/31 5:00
column5: 8/3" and that means the same thing.)

column1: \ - Use " -- " to start a new perusal (re-watching). (Since you're currently re-watching this
column2: it would make sense to move it up to your "In progress" section
column3: but you don't *have* to.)

column1: \ - This example means
column2: in plain English: "On the 28th of July
column4: I watched for an hour. I did the same on the 29th and 30th. Then over the weekend I went on a bender and watched 5 hours on the 31st and four hours on the 1st of Autust. I finished up the series by watching an hour on the 2nd and another hour on the 3rd. But I enjoyed the series so much that I started it over in September
column5: watching an hour on the 1st and another hour on the 2nd."

column1: \ "Escriba CafÃ©": Here's a more complex History
column2: where you're listening to a podcast with irregular episode lengths.

column1: \ - In this case you left the Dates Started
column2: Dates Finished
column3: and Length columns empty because you think you'll keep listening to a new episode once in a while. There is no definite state of being "in progress" or "done" with this podcast
column4: and therefore no definite total length either.

column1: \ - So this way
column2: the total length is the sum of what you've written in History
column3: the date started is the first date in History
column4: and the date finished is the last date in History. Technically this means the item is always in a "finished" state
column5: so it's best for items that you consume sporadically.

column1: \ - You can add extra text after the date
column2: such as (in this example) "Bella Luna" to indicate the title of the first episode. This extra text can appear either before or after the length.

column1: \ - This example means
column2: in plain English: "On the 12th of July
column4: I listened to the episode Bella Luna
column5: which was twenty minutes long. Then on the 13th I listened to another episode of the same length. Then on the same day I listened to a 45-minute episode. On the 17th I listened to a half-hour episode
column6: then from the 18th through the 21st I listened to one episode per day
column7: each of them half an hour long. On the 1st of August
column8: I listened to another half-hour episode called As sete Maravilhas."

column1: \ - If you wanted to track this History more simply
column2: you could just write an average episode length after the first date
column3: so this example would look like this: "2021/07/12 0:30
column7: 8/1". You could even omit the months wherever unnecessary: "2021/07/12 0:30

column1: \ Let's go back to our novel Goatsong
column2: way above in the "In progress" examples
column3: to take another look at its History column:

column1: 5|50% ğŸ“•Tom Holt - Goatsong: A Novel of Ancient Athens -- The Walled Orchard
\ Here's what we can learn from this example:
\ - Length can be in pages
column2: such as "5/1 p31" meaning "on 5/1 I read 31 pages".

column1: \ - But in this example we see "5/1 p31"
column2: with the "p" before the number. This means "on 5/1 I read up until page 31". This is useful for longer items like books and audiobooks
column3: where it's easier to see your stopping point than to calculate how much you read or listened to in a day.

column1: \ - To do the same with times
column2: use a leading hyphen: "5/1 -4:00" means "On the 1st of May I listened/watched up to the 4-hour mark."

column1: \ - "5/23 done" is shorthand for the last page
\ - This example means
column2: in plain English: "On the 1st of March
column4: I read up to page 31. On the 2nd I read up to page 54. From the 6th through the 15th I read 10 pages per day. Then on the 20th
column6: and on the 21st I finished the book."
